awd_titl_txt: TWC: Medium: Collaborative: Long-term Active User Authentication Using Multi-modal Profiles
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims at advancing the state-of-the-art in cybersecurity by developing efficient methods for generating novel biometric signatures and performing active and continuous user authentication. Current authentication procedures typically occur once at the initial log-in stage and involve user proxies such as passwords and smart cards which suffer from several vulnerabilities. This research addresses these limitations by developing probabilistic, generative models to represent multimodal biometrics of every user in the system, so that any significant deviation from the user-specific model flags the presence of an imposter. This novel technique specifically targets mitigation of masquerading attacks which are particularly challenging to detect as they are mostly carried out by insiders familiar with the activity patterns of the authorized user.  The approach enables identification of intruders before they can hijack a user session of an authorized individual who may have momentarily stepped away from his/her console.

The project also involves extensive usability tests for seamless integration of the authentication processes in real-life computer and network systems, thus ensuring that data about the behavior and performance of people using the network is fed-back and incorporated into future designs of the security protocols. The methods also readily extend to protecting both wired and wireless networks, and mobile devices.

por.por_cntn:
The major outcome of this project is an adaptive process to advance the current state of identity authentication in computer systems, using different individual biometrics traits. The project implemented an intelligent environment where a user identifies him/herself at a console and simply starts working, while continuous authentication occurs in the background, actively increasing the authentication processes when the evidence is weak, but invisible to the user, as he/she works without interruptions or performance compromises. In addition to using the cognitive biometric features, the project also developed an end-to-end system which incorporates face recognition, recognition based on keystroke dynamics and mouse movements of the user at the terminal. As part of the project, a large scale data collection campaign spanning a period of 4 months in two consecutive years was undertaken which resulted in one of the largest publicly available datasets consisting of keystroke dynamics and mouse movements from 291 users. The dataset was used to conduct a series of experiments using state-of-the-art algorithms and the results show that keystroke dynamics provides unique features to enable classification and verification of users working at a computer terminal with very little classification error.

The most important benefit of this project is its potential to dramatically reduce both masquerading and insider-based security challenges in an organizational setting. By changing the focus of person-to-machine authentication from being user-proxy-driven to becoming driven based on the uniquely identifiable traits of the user, unauthorized access to to information system resources can be significantly reduced or completely prevented.
